newsitem.title: TAIWAN: Daughter mum on China's ousted party chief Zhao.
newsitem.headline: Daughter mum on China's ousted party chief Zhao.

text.p: A daughter of China's disgraced Communist Party chief, Zhao Ziyang, has dodged Taiwan reporters' questions about his seven years in political limbo, saying only that Zhao was healthy.
"My father's health is good," Wang Yannan, a Beijing auction house executive who arrived in Taipei on Wednesday for a private visit, told the China Times newspaper.
"Everything in my family is fine. Thank you," she said.
The 42-year-old Wang, vice president of China Guardian Auctions Co Ltd, came to Taiwan for a three-day exhibition of Chinese art opening on September 6, a Taiwan organiser said.

As party general secretary in the late 1980s, Zhao was paramount leader Deng Xiaoping's hand-picked heir until he was toppled by party hardliners after the June 4, 1989 armed crackdown of the Tiananmen Square democracy movement.

Zhao, 77, fell within weeks of the crackdown, in which hundreds of protesters and some martial-law troops were killed. He was formally blamed for letting student-led protests spiral into a seditious "counter-revolutionary rebellion."

Zhao has endured virtual house arrest in a leafy Beijing courtyard ever since, making only quiet outings to a suburban Beijing golf course and occasional trips to other provinces with top party approval.
Recent photographs leaked to the Western media have shown Zhao to be trim and in apparently good health, though his hair has thinned and gone completely white.
Zhao's daughter made clear that she would not shed light on his daily life, let alone his opinion of regular speculation that he yearns for a political comeback.
Was it possible, she was asked by a Taipei television reporter, for Zhao to return to politics?
"I don't know," replied Wang, who has used her husband's surname since her father's fall from power. "I don't want to talk about this issue."
It is extremely rare for people linked to China's communist elite to travel to Nationalist-ruled Taiwan, which until the mid-1980s banned such visits.
Beijing has regarded Taiwan as a rebel province since the Nationalists were defeated by the Communists in 1949 and fled to the island.
